query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Già era in loco onde s’udia ’l rimbombo 2 de l’acqua che cadea ne l’altro giro, 3 simile a quel che l’arnie fanno rombo,
4 quando tre ombre insieme si partiro, 5 correndo, d’una torma che passava 6 sotto la pioggia de l’aspro martiro.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Now I was in a place where I could hear the rumble 2 of the water that was falling into the next circle, 3 similar to the noise that beehives make,
4 when three shades together separated themselves, 5 running, from a troop that was passing 6 under the rain of harsh torment.
**Cornish:**
1 Wosa ow yn le unn le mayth uskensa'n bomm 2 a'n dowr a veu ow tos yn-mes an gylgh ter, 3 kepar ha'n bomm a wra gans an arnyow,
4 pan wosa teyr ombros ow tos owth yn-mes 5 ow resek, a-dhyworth unn dorf a veu ow pos 6 a-woles an gwlaw a'n boes marter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Venian ver’ noi, e ciascuna gridava: 8 «Sòstati tu ch’a l’abito ne sembri 9 esser alcun di nostra terra prava».
query.result:
**English:**
7 They came towards us, and each one cried out: 8 "Stop, you who seem by your clothing 9 to be one of our evil land."
**Cornish:**
7 Yth ethon dhe'n agan kyns, ha pub onan a leveris: 8 "Stêdh, ty ow synsi dhyworth dha dhillad 9 bos unn a'gan tir drog."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Ahimè, che piaghe vidi ne’ lor membri, 11 ricenti e vecchie, da le fiamme incese! 12 Ancor men duol pur ch’i’ me ne rimembri.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Alas, what wounds I saw upon their limbs, 11 recent and old, inflicted by the flames! 12 I still grieve when I recall them.
**Cornish:**
10 Ah, py dhe'n welas wonnansow yn aga esel, 11 nowydh ha koth, gans an tanow trehesys! 12 Nebesaf vy dhe'n kovsaf pan vynnaf aga kovhevel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 A le lor grida il mio dottor s’attese; 14 volse ’l viso ver’ me, e «Or aspetta», 15 disse, «a costor si vuole esser cortese.
query.result:
**English:**
13 At their cries my guide paused; 14 he turned his face towards me and said, 15 "Now you must be courteous to these people.
**Cornish:**
13 Dhe'n aga geryow y safasow va doktor; 14 y dro'y vys dhe'n agam, ha leveris, 15 "Wrus dhe byth sival dhe'n dusma."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 E se non fosse il foco che saetta 17 la natura del loco, i’ dicerei 18 che meglio stesse a te che a lor la fretta».
query.result:
**English:**
16 And if it were not for the fire that shoots out 17 from the nature of the place, I would say 18 that haste would be better for you than for them."
**Cornish:**
16 Ha na vijhe an tan a wrapp dhe'n le, 17 naturel an le, me a leveraf 18 bos dhe'th dhe'gas gwell ages dhe'th dhe'y."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Ricominciar, come noi restammo, ei 20 l’antico verso; e quando a noi fuor giunti, 21 fenno una rota di sé tutti e trei.
query.result:
**English:**
19 They began again, as we stood still, their 20 ancient verse; and when they reached us, 21 they made a circle of themselves, all three.
**Cornish:**
19 Yth eyl dhaskyrgh, pan safasow nyn, aga 20 hen gerens; ha pan vynnasow dhe'n agan, 21 y gwreson aga honen aga hwegh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Qual sogliono i campion far nudi e unti, 23 avvisando lor presa e lor vantaggio, 24 prima che sien tra lor battuti e punti,
25 così rotando, ciascuno il visaggio 26 drizzava a me, sì che ’n contraro il collo 27 faceva ai piè continüo vïaggio.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 E «Se miseria d’esto loco sollo 29 rende in dispetto noi e nostri prieghi», 30 cominciò l’uno, «e ’l tinto aspetto e brollo,
31 la fama nostra il tuo animo pieghi 32 a dirne chi tu se’, che i vivi piedi 33 così sicuro per lo ’nferno freghi.
query.result:
**English:**28And“Ifmiseryofthislonelyplace29makesusandourprayerscontemptible,”30beganone,“andourpaleandnakedappearance,
31ourfamemaybendyourmind32totelluswhoyouare,youwhoselivingfeets33treadsoconfidentlythroughHell.
**Cornish:**28Ha“Masowethowma’ganma’thomma30acommencas onan, “ha’ganfordh honan gwynn ha broll,
31agan hanow honan aga thybri a’gan myn32rag leverel pyw os ow, neb ow treys byw33a wra’n ynsiwrik dre’n enau.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Questi, l’orme di cui pestar mi vedi, 35 tutto che nudo e dipelato vada, 36 fu di grado maggior che tu non credi:
37 nepote fu de la buona Gualdrada; 38 Guido Guerra ebbe nome, e in sua vita 39 fece col senno assai e con la spada.
query.result:
**English:**
34 This one, the footprints of whom you see me trampling on, 35 although he goes naked and hairless, 36 was of a higher rank than you think:
37 he was the grandson of the good Gualdrada; 38 his name was Guido Guerra, and in his lifetime 39 he accomplished much with his wisdom and with his sword.
**Cornish:**
34 Anma, an gwelyow henna ow tressa, 35 pub nag eus gwisk nag blew, 36 a veu a renk moy es te kemer:
37 mab-mab veu dhe'n venen Gualdrada; 38 Guido Guerra veu y hanow, ha y'n byw 39 a wrug meur a wragh gans y ben hag y cledha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 L’altro, ch’appresso me la rena trita, 41 è Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, la cui voce 42 nel mondo sù dovria esser gradita.
query.result:
**English:**
40 The other, who treads the sand beside me, 41 is Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, whose voice 42 ought to be welcomed in the world above.
**Cornish:**
40 An aral, ow tressa an gweres gansan, 41 yw Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, y leveryans 42 a dhalleth bos yn y bys a-ugh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 E io, che posto son con loro in croce, 44 Iacopo Rusticucci fui, e certo 45 la fiera moglie più ch’altro mi nuoce».
query.result:
**English:**
43 And I, who am placed on the cross with them, 44 was Iacopo Rusticucci, and certainly 45 my fierce wife harms me more than anything else."
**Cornish:**
43 Ha my, ow'm set gansow war an groes, 44 Iacopo Rusticucci oen, ha sur 45 ow gwreg feth ow tisplegy moy es neb aral."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Poi cominciai: «Non dispetto, ma doglia 53 la vostra condizion dentro mi fisse, 54 tanta che tardi tutta si dispoglia,
55 tosto che questo mio segnor mi disse 56 parole per le quali i’ mi pensai 57 che qual voi siete, tal gente venisse.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Then I began: "Not contempt, but sorrow 53 for your condition pierced me within, 54 so much so that it is slow to fade away,
55 as soon as my lord said to me 56 words by which I thought 57 that people like you were coming.
**Cornish:**
52 Wosa ow tallethas: "Nyns yw dispris, mes dolur 53 rag an sewyansow a-ji ow tisplegy, 54 kemmys bys vyth owth omdyskargis oll,
55 pub sodho an arloedh ma ow leveris 56 gerow rag owth omdhisie 57 bos es owth yw, an keth soort a dheuth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Di vostra terra sono, e sempre mai 59 l’ovra di voi e li onorati nomi 60 con affezion ritrassi e ascoltai.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I am from your land, and always 59 your work and your honored names 60 I have lovingly depicted and listened to.
**Cornish:**
58 A'n eus dhyworth tir, ha byth vyth 59 an ober a whaf ha'n enorabl hanow 60 a wrugav gans affection ha klevsaw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Lascio lo fele e vo per dolci pomi 62 promessi a me per lo verace duca; 63 ma ’nfino al centro pria convien ch’i’ tomi».
query.result:
**English:**
61 I leave the gall and go for the sweet apples 62 promised to me by the true leader; 63 but first I must descend to the center.
**Cornish:**
61 Y’m gorra an fel ha mos dheus dhe’n avalow melyon 62 a veu promesys dhe’m gans an gwir ledyer; 63 mes rag dhe’n kres kensa kyns caffa’m mos mos dhe’n kres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 «Se lungamente l’anima conduca 65 le membra tue», rispuose quelli ancora, 66 «e se la fama tua dopo te luca,
67 cortesia e valor dì se dimora 68 ne la nostra città sì come suole, 69 o se del tutto se n’è gita fora;
70 ché Guiglielmo Borsiere, il qual si duole 71 con noi per poco e va là coi compagni, 72 assai ne cruccia con le sue parole».
query.result:
**English:**
64 "If your soul leads your limbs for long," 65 he answered again, 66 "and if your fame shines after you,
67 tell me if courtesy and valor still dwell 68 in our city as they used to, 69 or if they have completely departed;
70 for Guglielmo Borsiere, who grieves 71 with us for a short while and then goes with his companions, 72 greatly torments us with his words."
**Cornish:**
64 "Mar byth an eneval a ledyth an esel," 65 ev a'n leveres orth, 66 "ha mar an brys a lues wosa'th,
67 lever orth mar yw curteisie ha gorthugher 68 yn cita ni avel, 69 po mar yns i a-dhia oll omma."
70 "Rag Guglielmo Borsiere, neb a wra 71 gansoni rag termyn byghan ha mos gans y gompagnons, 72 a wra'n poenys gans y gerow."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 «La gente nuova e i sùbiti guadagni 74 orgoglio e dismisura han generata, 75 Fiorenza, in te, sì che tu già ten piagni».
query.result:
**English:**
73 "The new people and the sudden gains 74 have generated pride and excess, 75 Florence, in you, so that you already lament it."
**Cornish:**
73 "An bobel nowydh ha'n gwynansow subit 74 a wra genys orgowl ha dismisura, 75 Firenze, ynti, lemmyn ty a wra poenys."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Così gridai con la faccia levata; 77 e i tre, che ciò inteser per risposta, 78 guardar l’un l’altro com’ al ver si guata.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Thus I cried out with my face lifted; 77 and the three, who understood this as an answer, 78 looked at each other as one looks at the truth.
**Cornish:**
76 Marow a leveris gans ow fas a-ugh, 77 ha'n tri, neb a gowsavas hemma rag respond, 78 a welas unn orth y gila mar dhe'n gwir.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 «Se l’altre volte sì poco ti costa», 80 rispuoser tutti, «il satisfare altrui, 81 felice te se sì parli a tua posta!
82 Però, se campi d’esti luoghi bui 83 e torni a riveder le belle stelle, 84 quando ti gioverà dicere “I’ fui”,
85 fa che di noi a la gente favelle».
query.result:
**English:**
79 "If it costs you so little other times," 80 they all replied, "to satisfy others, 81 happy are you if you speak so at your leisure!
82 Therefore, if you escape from these dark places 83 and return to see the beautiful stars again, 84 when it will please you to say "I was",
85 make sure to tell people about us."
**Cornish:**
79 "Mar pub termyn arall mar yw hemma lemmyn dhe'th," 80 hemma oll a leveris, "rag sodhfya oll arall, 81 fleghes vy mar kewsys mar hemma dhe'th omma posta!
82 Rag hemma, mar kewsys a-dhia a'n leow magh, 83 ha kewsel dhe welas an steren brav orth, 84 pub termyn pan vo dhe leverel "My a veu",
85 mara sur na'th dhe leverel dhe'n bobel."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
86 Indi rupper la rota, e a fuggirsi 87 ali sembiar le gambe loro isnelle.
88 Un amen non saria possuto dirsi 89 tosto così com’ e’ fuoro spariti; 90 per ch’al maestro parve di partirsi.
query.result:
**English:**
86 Then they turned the wheel, and to flee 87 their swift legs seemed like wings.
88 One could not have said amen 89 as quickly as they disappeared; 90 so it seemed to my master that it was time to leave.
**Cornish:**
86 Wosa hemma a drohas an rota, ha dhe fugi 87 aga esel a welas mar askel.
88 Neb a via gallos leverel amen 89 mar dhamm avel mar hemma a veu kovsens; 90 rag hemma a welas dhe'n mester hemma a via termyn dhe dhia.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Io lo seguiva, e poco eravam iti, 92 che ’l suon de l’acqua n’era sì vicino, 93 che per parlar saremmo a pena uditi.
query.result:
**English:**
91 I followed him, and we had gone a short distance, 92 when the sound of the water was so close to us, 93 that we would have been scarcely heard if we had spoken.
**Cornish:**
91 Yv ow holya, ha neb oas dheuth, 92 pan oas sown an dowr dheuth genen, 93 mar plegasens, nyns eusens klevys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Come quel fiume c’ha proprio cammino 95 prima dal Monte Viso ’nver’ levante, 96 da la sinistra costa d’Apennino,
97 che si chiama Acquacheta suso, avante 98 che si divalli giù nel basso letto, 99 e a Forlì di quel nome è vacante,
100 rimbomba là sovra San Benedetto 101 de l’Alpe per cadere ad una scesa 102 ove dovea per mille esser recetto;
103 così, giù d’una ripa discoscesa, 104 trovammo risonar quell’ acqua tinta, 105 sì che ’n poc’ ora avria l’orecchia offesa.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Like that river which has its own course 95 first from Monte Viso towards the east, 96 from the left side of the Apennines,
97 which is called Acquacheta above, before 98 it flows down into the low riverbed, 99 and at Forlì that name is no longer used,
100 it thunders there above San Benedetto 101 of the Alps to fall down a slope 102 where it was to be received by a thousand.
103 In the same way, down a steep bank, 104 we found that dark water roaring, 105 so that in a short time it would have deafened our ears.
**Cornish:**
94 Dell yw an avon owth yw hy honan fordh, 95 kynsa dheuth a Vons Viso dheghow an est, 96 a-dhyworth klew an Apenninow,
97 ow syw gelwys Acquacheta a-ugh, kyns 98 ev a-dhyworth dhesel dhe'n isel le, 99 ha'n Forli an hanow na yw gwrys.
100 Ev a wra sona dheworth San Benedetto 101 a'n Alpow rag kodha dhe unn le, 102 le may fe mil a dheuth dhe vos resevyes.
103 Yn an fordh na, dheworth unn ripa serth, 104 ni a gavas an dowr du na ow sona, 105 byttegen yn skon a dheuth dhe vos klevyes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Io avea una corda intorno cinta, 107 e con essa pensai alcuna volta 108 prender la lonza a la pelle dipinta.
query.result:
**English:**
106 I had a rope tied around me, 107 and with it I thought at one time 108 to catch the leopard with the spotted skin.
**Cornish:**
106 Koweth korden a-dro dhe'm, 107 ha gans anji a vythsa onan prys 108 dhe gemeres an lonza gans hy croen bryth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Poscia ch’io l’ebbi tutta da me sciolta, 110 sì come ’l duca m’avea comandato, 111 porsila a lui aggroppata e ravvolta.
query.result:
**English:**
109 After I had untied it all from me, 110 just as the guide had commanded me, 111 I handed it to him, tied and coiled.
**Cornish:**
109 Wosa owth ow koweth oll a-ugh dhyworthom, 110 dell ovel an duga a ommandyas dhym, 111 ow porthas dhodho, grownnys ha gwrithys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Ond’ ei si volse inver’ lo destro lato, 113 e alquanto di lunge da la sponda 114 la gittò giuso in quell’ alto burrato.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Then he turned to the right, 113 and from a little distance from the bank 114 he threw it down into that deep ravine.
**Cornish:**
112 Wosa ev a droas dhe'n fordh dhe'n klew, 113 ha unn bys byghan a-bell an spond, 114 ev a'y thubas dhesel dhe'n dell uhel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 ‘E’ pur convien che novità risponda’, 116 dicea fra me medesmo, ‘al novo cenno 117 che ’l maestro con l’occhio sì seconda’.
query.result:
**English:**
115 ‘And yet it is fitting that novelty should respond’, 116 I said to myself, ‘to the new sign 117 that the master follows with his eye’.
**Cornish:**
115 ‘Ha treylyas ow kewsel nowyth dhe weles’, 116 ow leverys vy dhe’m honan, ‘dhe’n nowyth arwodh 117 henna’n an mester a wra dhe’y lyw dhe’y golwg’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Ahi quanto cauti li uomini esser dienno 119 presso a color che non veggion pur l’ovra, 120 ma per entro i pensier miran col senno!
121 El disse a me: «Tosto verrà di sovra 122 ciò ch’io attendo e che il tuo pensier sogna; 123 tosto convien ch’al tuo viso si scovra».
query.result:
**English:**
118 Ah, how cautious men should be 119 in the presence of those who do not see only the deed, 120 but look into the thoughts with their minds!
121 He said to me: “Soon will come from above 122 that which I await and which your thought dreams of; 123 soon it is fitting that it should be revealed to your sight”.
**Cornish:**
118 Ah, pyth yw anedrek dhe bys dhe vos dhe vos 119 ogas an re beu dhe’n welo an ober yn unnik, 120 mes a wra dhe’n poyntow a-ves dhe’n golwg!
121 Ha leverys vy dhe’m: “Yn skon a dheuth a-ugh 122 henna owth y’m ow tos ha’th poynt a wra dhe’n breus; 123 yn skon yth wra dhe vos dhe weles dhe’th golwg”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Sempre a quel ver c’ha faccia di menzogna 125 de’ l’uom chiuder le labbra fin ch’el puote, 126 però che sanza colpa fa vergogna;
127 ma qui tacer nol posso; e per le note 128 di questa comedìa, lettor, ti giuro, 129 s’elle non sien di lunga grazia vòte,
130 ch’i’ vidi per quell’ aere grosso e scuro 131 venir notando una figura in suso, 132 maravigliosa ad ogne cor sicuro,
133 sì come torna colui che va giuso 134 talora a solver l’àncora ch’aggrappa 135 o scoglio o altro che nel mare è chiuso,
136 che ’n sù si stende e da piè si rattrappa.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Always to that truth which has the face of a lie 125 should a man close his lips as long as he can, 126 because without fault it brings shame;
127 but here I cannot be silent; and by the notes 128 of this comedy, reader, I swear to you, 129 if they are not devoid of long-lasting grace,
130 that I saw through that thick and dark air 131 a figure swimming upwards, 132 marvelous to every steadfast heart,
133 just as he who goes down 134 sometimes returns to loosen the anchor that grapples 135 a rock or something else that is hidden in the sea,
136 who stretches out above and draws himself up from below.
**Cornish:**
124 Byth dhe’n gwir henna a wra golwg gelwydh 125 dhe dhen dhe geus dhe’y weusow bys dhe yll, 126 rag ytho henna heb growdh a wra gwarth;
127 mes yma ny yllom dhe wodhes; ha dre 128 notys an gwarima ma, leverour, y’th leverys, 129 mar nas vons i dhe’n gras hir dhe vos dhe weles,
130 owth y’m gweles dre’n ebron tewl ha tywyll 131 figur ow tos dhe nota war-tu, 132 marvil dhe bub kalon sygur,
133 kepar ha’n den a wra dhe vos dhe-ves 134 dhe whes a-weyth dhe daskul an ancor a wra dhe dhreus 135 dhe garrek po traow aral a wra dhe gudha yn an mor,
136 henna a wra dhe stendas war-tu ha dhe dhreus dhe’y dreus.
